awd_titl_txt: Optimizing Student Team Skill Development using Evidence-Based Strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
The critical importance of effective teamwork in engineering is widely recognized. Surprisingly, however, relatively little is known about how to develop teamwork skills in higher education classes, including what factors contribute to effective teamwork, their relative importance in a team's overall performance, and the underlying individual and interpersonal dynamics. Increasing numbers of engineering instructors are adopting instructional practices relying on teamwork, yet many instructors simply form student teams and hope the members individually and collectively learn on their own how to work in teams and succeed in their task(s).  Instructors do this because they do not have guidance for a better approach. This research project aims to address this gap in faculty knowledge.

The empirical studies conducted as part of this project build on research in engineering education, cognitive psychology, social psychology, and other fields in a coordinated large-scale research project that will provide faculty with needed knowledge and tools to ensure that students learn team skills. The research team is conducting seven separate studies measuring the impact of teamwork training, experience working in teams, practice rating the teamwork of fictitious team members, and giving and receiving peer feedback.  The research is measuring each of these effects in real teams on three learning outcomes: improved teamwork knowledge, improved ability to evaluate teamwork, and improved ability to function effectively in teams. These studies will result in practical recommendations for time-pressed faculty to implement.

por.por_cntn:
CATME System for forming and managing student teams was already popular at the start of this project - it had been used by approximately 700,000 students worldwide taught by more than 12,000 instructors at more than 1800 institutions in 76 countries. The goal of this project was to determine the effect of multiple approaches on improving students' team skills and their ability to evaluate team skills. The three approaches were (1) teaching students a common model of teamwork, (2) repeated experience working in teams and providing feedback to teammates, and (3) receiving different types of feedback on their own performance in teams. The project also recognized that the two outcomes - the ability to function effectively on a team and the ability to evaluate teamwork - reinforce each other.

Through multiple experiments leading to various publications, this research identified an improved method for teaching students a common model of teamwork and showed that students with a better understanding of that common model both function more effectively on teams and are better at evaluating their teamwork skills and those of their teammates. Whereas many instructors believe that students only learn teamwork through experience, not only was that common model of teamwork important, but this research showed that experience working in teams mostly helps students learn team skills and the ability to rate them if those team experiences include the use of peer evaluation for students to give and receive feedback.

In testing various feedback methods, the project team faced some experimental challenges, particularly with the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, but there are early indications that automated feedback from the CATME system has some benefit, that written comments from peers has an additional benefit, but that intensive coaching from the instructor adds little beyond the impact of the first two - most likely because students are particularly motivated by feedback from peers.

The impact of this research is bolstered by the online system used to conduct the research and used to enact the findings of the research. To date, the CATME system has been used by 1.8 million students of 23,865 instructors at 2603 institutions in 88 countries. The use of the system continues to grow in spite of the need to license system on a non-profit basis starting in 2017 in response to the maintenance cost of supporting the system to meet the demands of 260,000 new students per year using the system. Five years after licensing was implemented, the system still reaches more than 150,000 new students per year, and license fees provide support for system maintenance, new feature development, and technical support. The system is still used by a diverse population of small and large, research-focused and teaching focused, and geographically distributed institutions. 


Last Modified: 08/03/2022
Modified by: Matthew W Ohland
